Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Bariatric and Endoscopic Interventions on MASLD

Trial_Design.evidence: A randomised controlled trial was conducted with participants meeting obesity criteria and MASLD diagnosis.

Participants.evidence: Participants were recruited from a tertiary care center.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB), vertical sleeve gastrectomy (VSG), adjustable gastric banding (AGB), or endoscopic therapies like intragastric balloon (IGB) and endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (ESG). The control group received standard lifestyle modification.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the effectiveness of bariatric and endoscopic interventions on metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the resolution of hepatic steatosis, measured over 12 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 200 participants were randomised: 50 to RYGB, 50 to VSG, 50 to AGB, and 50 to endoscopic therapies.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 48 in RYGB, 47 in VSG, 46 in AGB, and 45 in endoscopic therapies, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: RYGB showed the highest resolution of steatosis (95%), followed by VSG (60%), AGB (42%), and endoscopic therapies (notable short-term improvements).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 3% in RYGB and 1% in VSG experiencing gastrointestinal side effects.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by the National Institutes of Health.
